sections.title: Overview
sections.description:
Freighter is Stellar's flagship wallet. We had a browser extension but no mobile app, so when someone asked "how do I get started with Stellar?" we didn't have a great answer.

A small team: three engineers, one PM, and me as the sole designer. Five months to ship before Meridian, our annual conference where attendees would use it live.

It launched at Meridian as planned. ~2k daily active users, ~31k monthly.
sections.footnotes: I also designed and built freighter.app in Framer.

sections.title: Home
sections.description:
The home screen answers three questions: what do I have, what's it worth, and what's changed? Balance sits at the top. Below, Tokens and Collectibles tabs let users navigate holdings without overwhelming the default view.

Loading states preserve layout dimensions, preventing content shift as data arrives. Primary actions are minimal: Add, Send, Swap, Copy. Everything else lives a tap away. Crypto wallets often try to surface everything at once. We wanted calm.

sections.title: History
sections.description:
Transaction history on Stellar can get noisy. Trustline changes, path payments, claimable balances. Most of it means nothing to someone who just wants to know "did my payment go through?"

We wrote human-readable summaries for each operation type. "Swapped XLM â†’ USDC" instead of raw operation data. Tapping expands full details: status, rate, fee, XDR. Progressive disclosure. Clarity first, completeness on request.

sections.title: Discover
sections.description:
This is our main differentiator. No other Stellar wallet has a dedicated screen for ecosystem apps. We wanted Freighter to feel less like a vault and more like a portal.

We launched with ten curated dApps including Blend, Phoenix, StellarX, and Allbridge. Each opens in an in-app browser with WalletConnect handling the connection. You never leave Freighter.

For developers, Discover is distribution. For users, it's access.

sections.title: Collectibles
sections.description:
Collectibles on Stellar are typically Soroban-based NFTs (like Stellar Frogs) or domain names (Soroban Domains). The Collectibles tab groups them by collection with a count badge.

The detail view shows metadata: name, collection, token ID, description. Actions: View, Send, or overflow menu for refresh metadata, save to photos, hide, or report as spam. Hidden collectibles matter. Spam NFTs are a real problem, so users can hide unwanted items and report them.

sections.title: Send
sections.description:
Sending should be trivial. The flow: recipient selection (address, contact picker, QR scan), asset selection, amount entry with real-time USD conversion, review, biometric confirmation, then success or failure.

Each step validates before proceeding. Errors caught early, not at final submission. The percentage shortcuts (25%, 50%, 75%, Max) account for minimum XLM reserves so users don't accidentally lock themselves out.

sections.title: Swap
sections.description:
Swap uses Stellar's built-in orderbook DEX. We query Horizon's strictSendPaths endpoint for path finding, which returns optimal routes through the orderbook.

The flow mirrors Send: select token to swap from, select token to receive, enter amount, review, confirm. Swap Settings expose slippage tolerance (default 1%), transaction timeout, and fee. Tucked away but accessible for power users.

sections.title: Transactions
sections.description:
Stellar transactions can contain multiple operations, each with different implications. Signing something you don't understand is how people lose funds.

We integrated Blockaid for real-time simulation. Three risk levels: Malicious (block and explain), Suspicious (warn and let user decide), Safe (proceed). Messaging is specific: "This contract has drained funds" rather than generic "Dangerous."

The UI shows simulated results before signing. Expanding reveals full details. Progressive disclosure: human-readable first, raw data for those who want it.

sections.title: Takeaways
sections.description:
If I did it again, I'd collapse the early phases and push toward polish faster. The phased approach (MVP, beta, v1) made sense on paper but created alignment friction in practice. More time for craft, less time reconciling version definitions in Slack.

Thanks to the engineering team (Cassio, Leo, Danilo), Keeks for keeping us on track, Piyal and Aristides for support across the extension and backend, and the broader Stellar team.
sections.footnotes:
next time: fewer versions, faster convergence

Launched September 2025 at Stellar Meridian.

sections.title: Overview
sections.description:
Snack is curated lists, designed to be shared. You collect links around a theme and publish them as a clean, standalone page. No profile clutter, no social graph, no follower counts.

The constraint is intentional. Links only. No images, no embeds, no text blocks. This keeps lists lightweight and forces clarity: if something's worth adding, it earns its spot.

sections.title: Menu
sections.description:
The menu is where you manage everything. Your lists, your profile, your settings. It stays out of the way until you need it.

No nested navigation, no hamburger menus hiding critical features. Everything is one tap away. The goal was to keep the interface flat: see what you have, act on it, move on.

sections.title: What exists now
sections.description:
I looked at Linktree, Bento, and Notion. The first two are identity-centric: you have one profile, and links live alongside everything else about you. The creator is the main event, not the content.

Notion was simple enough for managing lists, but sharing was clunky. Lists lived alongside notes rather than as standalone pages.

I wanted something content-first. A tool where the list is the product.

sections.title: The $30K lesson
sections.description:
Last year, I spent $30,000 to hire a dev agency for a software idea I believed in. After six months, we had a working MVP. Too costly to continue, not enough distribution to justify the spend.

Then Claude Code became available. I rebuilt from scratch. Since May 2025, I've shipped the entire product and more, maintaining it solo on a $20/month subscription. What took six months and five figures now takes afternoons.

sections.title: Creating a list
sections.description:
Creating a list takes under a minute. Set an emoji, add a title, paste your links.

The fastest flow is clipboard-first: copy a URL, paste it directly. Snack scrapes the metadata automatically (title, description, favicon) so you don't format anything. The goal was muscle memory over form-filling.

One action, one result. No friction between "I found something good" and "it's in my list."

sections.title: Editing a list
sections.description:
There's no separate edit mode. If you're the creator, the list is simply editable. Click the emoji to change it. Click the title to rename. Drag to reorder. Paste from your clipboard to add one link or twenty.

This collapses the gap between viewing and editing to zero. You're always in the right context.

I don't love the visual style of emojis, but they're the most unopinionated choice for this use case. Intentionally generic.

sections.title: Sharing a list
sections.description:
Sharing is just a copy-link button. No share modals, no platform pickers. This mirrors how people actually share things: paste into iMessage, drop into a Twitter DM.

Dynamic OG images are generated automatically based on the emoji, title, and username. Every list looks good when shared without any manual setup. The small things that make sharing feel effortless.

sections.title: Saving from X
sections.description:
The browser extension lets you save links from any Twitter thread in one or two clicks. Find a thread with interesting links, click the extension, and save them all to an existing list or create a new one on the spot.

This bridges the gap between discovery and curation. You don't have to leave the page, open Snack, and manually paste. The flow stays unbroken.

sections.title: List stats
sections.description:
Analytics show three things: total links across all your lists, total views, and how many times your lists have been saved by others.

You can also drill into each list individually to see how it's performing. The focus is on signal over noise: enough to understand what's resonating, not so much that you're drowning in dashboards.

sections.title: Takeaways
sections.description:
Building Snack reinforced a few things I already believed but now have receipts for. Constraints sharpen products. One-click interactions compound into habits. And with the right tools, a solo designer can ship and maintain software that would have required a team two years ago.

The hardest part isn't building. It's resisting the urge to add more.

sections.title: Overview
sections.description:
Stellar Lab is where developers experiment with the Stellar network. Build transactions, sign them, simulate, submit, explore smart contracts.

The old Lab was built by engineers years ago and hadn't been touched since. It worked, but it looked like it worked. Meanwhile, Stellar's smart contracts platform (Soroban) was launching, and the Lab needed to support entirely new features.

My job was to redesign it: bring the visual language in line with the rest of Stellar's products, support smart contracts, and do this without alienating developers who'd built muscle memory around the existing flow. Raise the quality dramatically while preserving the mental model.

sections.title: Stellar Design System
sections.description:
This project became the first real implementation of Stellar Design System v3. We had components, tokens, and documentation. What we didn't have was a complex, form-heavy developer tool putting pressure on all of it at once.

The Lab exposed gaps immediately. Form validation patterns fell apart with fifteen fields on screen. The type scale needed adjustments for dense technical content. Some components didn't exist yet.

Every edge case became a contribution back to SDS. Input states for long cryptographic strings. Error messaging for transaction validation. The sort of details that only surface when you're building something real.

sections.title: Save to local storage
sections.description:
Developers were constantly copying and pasting. Keys, transaction XDR, contract IDs. The same strings, over and over, across different parts of the tool.

So we built a save system. Keypairs, API requests, transactions, smart contract IDs. Everything lives in browser local storage, organised by network: Testnet for experimentation, Mainnet for production, Futurenet for bleeding-edge features.

Building a transaction? Prefill the source account from saved keypairs. Found a contract worth revisiting? Save the ID. Small conveniences that compound into something that actually feels considered.

sections.title: Account
sections.description:
Creating an account on Stellar means generating a keypair, then funding it. On Testnet and Futurenet, Friendbot handles funding with 10,000 test XLM.

The old flow required mental overhead. Generate keys, copy them somewhere, navigate to a different page, paste, fund. The new flow keeps everything together. Generate, optionally save with a name, fund with one click.

Saved keypairs display the account's XLM balance, last saved date, and quick actions: copy public key, reveal secret key, fund if unfunded. Account management as a proper dashboard rather than disconnected utilities.

sections.title: Transactions
sections.description:
The transaction builder is the heart of the Lab. Source account, sequence number, base fee, memo, time bounds, then operations. Every field has validation, helper text, and links to docs. "Fetch next sequence" pulls the right number automatically. "Set to 5 min from now" handles time bounds without timestamp math.

Signing was harder. Transactions can require multiple signatures: secret key, browser wallet, hardware wallet, or pre-computed signature. The temptation was to hide this behind tabs.

We show everything at once. Four cards, stacked. It looks dense because it is dense, but it matches how developers actually work with multi-sig.

sections.title: API Explorer
sections.description:
The API Explorer lets you test Stellar's RPC methods and Horizon endpoints directly in the browser. No Postman, no curl, no context switching.

Three categories: RPC Query Methods for reading blockchain data, Simulation & Fees for validating transactions before execution, Transaction Execution for submitting to the network.

Each method has typed inputs and inline documentation. Submit a request, see the response, save it or share a link. Instead of describing a failing request over Slack, just send a URL. The design challenge was density: some endpoints have a dozen parameters. Collapsible sections and sensible defaults kept the common case simple.

sections.title: Smart Contracts
sections.description:
Soroban brought smart contracts to Stellar, and the Lab needed to support the full lifecycle.

Contract Explorer is the entry point. Paste a contract ID and get everything: creation date, creator, Wasm hash, source code, storage state, version history, and generated bindings for TypeScript, Rust, Python, Java. Invoke methods directly from the browser with type hints from the contract spec.

Smart Contract List shows contracts on the network. Upload and Deploy handles the deployment flow. The goal: make smart contracts feel as accessible as the rest of the Lab, whether you're exploring or shipping.

sections.title: Transaction Dashboard
sections.description:
The dashboard gives you a real-time view of submitted transactions. Status, hash, timestamps, links to block explorers.

This was a late addition based on feedback. The old Lab had no memory of what you'd submitted. Send a transaction, see a success message, then nothing. Want to verify it landed? Copy the hash and check an external explorer.

The dashboard keeps a running log. Pending transactions show status as they propagate. Completed ones link to their ledger entry. Failed ones surface the error. A small feature that makes the Lab feel like an integrated environment.

sections.title: Takeaways
sections.description:
Developer tools have a different relationship with complexity. The instinct to simplify, to hide options, can make things harder for people who know exactly what they need. The signing flow shows four methods at once. It looks busy, but developers working with multi-sig don't want to hunt through tabs.

Small conveniences compound. Saving a keypair takes two seconds. Prefilling from it takes one. None feel like features alone, but together they're the difference between a tool that fights you and one that gets out of the way.

Redesigning something people use is a trust exercise. You earn it by respecting what worked before.
sections.footnotes: Thanks to Jane (PM), Jeesun and Iveta (Eng). Built on Stellar Design System v3.
